aboutView.title: About This Project
aboutView.aboutDescription1: This platform is designed to help users learn the Mon language through interactive lessons, implemented of AI, and various useful application of the language through mini-apps.
aboutView.aboutDescription2: The platform also includes features such as a virtual keyboard for typing in Mon, dictionary for Mon-Thai translation, and other various tools.
aboutView.aboutDescription3: Developed by Barnista, this project aims to preserve and promote the Mon language and culture through modern technology, making it accessible to a wider audience.

communityView.title: Community
communityView.description: Join our community to discuss, share, and learn more about the Mon language and culture. Connect with fellow learners and enthusiasts.
communityView.description2: We are on X (Twitter), Facebook, Twitch, YouTube, Discord, and Telegram. Join us to share your thoughts, ask questions, and participate in discussions.

doubleConsonantView.description: In the Mon language, double consonants are two consonants overlapping each other. The purpose is to make writing concise and space-efficient. Double consonants are divided into 2 types:
doubleConsonantView.descriptionType1: It is a typography with simple rules. The reading is to pronounce both consonants, the main and the overlapped consonants, by reading from top to bottom, for example:
doubleConsonantView.descriptionType2: It is a typography with legacy rules derived from Pali-Sansakrit. The main consonant will turn into the final consonant for the consonant positioned at the start. The consonant that is overlapped will be pronounced on its own or combined with the following vowel and/or final consonant. To understand this, please see the example below:
doubleConsonantView.descriptionTable2: Please open section Consonants below and try to remember the context that: Mon consonants are divided into 5 rows, each row has 5 consonants and the remaining 10 are the zero-consonants, totaling 35 characters.
doubleConsonantView.ruleType21: Each row is divided into 2 types of consonants:
doubleConsonantView.ruleType22: The 1st - 3rd - 5th consonants of every row are classified as final consonants. Can overlap the 2nd - 4th consonant or overlap itself (except ·Åö and ·Äç)
doubleConsonantView.ruleType23: The 2nd - 4th consonants of every row are classified as overlapped consonants. Cannot overlap the 1st - 3rd - 5th consonant and cannot overlap itself.
doubleConsonantView.ruleNo21: The 1st consonant can overlap on the 2nd consonant and can overlap itself (within the same row)
doubleConsonantView.ruleNo22: The 3rd consonant can overlap on the 4th consonant and can overlap itself (within the same row)
doubleConsonantView.ruleNo23: The 5th consonant can overlap on all consonants and can overlap itself (within the same row)
doubleConsonantView.noteType1: The 11 compound consonants are not considered double consonants.

getStartView.title: Get Start
getStartView.getStartDescription1: The Mon alphabet represents a writing system of significant historical and typological interest in Southeast Asia. It is derived from the ancient Brahmi script lineage and has been instrumental in the transmission of TheravƒÅda Buddhist texts and Mon cultural heritage.
getStartView.getStartDescription2: The Mon alphabet is the writing system used for the Mon language, an Austroasiatic language spoken mainly in Myanmar (Burma) and Thailand by the Mon people.
getStartView.getStartDescription3: It‚Äôs historically important because Mon was one of the earliest languages in mainland Southeast Asia to be written down ‚Äî and its script influenced the writing systems of neighboring languages, including Burmese, Thai, and Khmer.
getStartView.historyDescription1: The Mon language is one of the oldest languages still spoken in mainland Southeast Asia, with a history stretching back well over a millennium. It belongs to the Monic branch of the Austroasiatic language family, making it a relative of Khmer (Cambodian) and distantly related to Vietnamese and other languages in the region.
getStartView.historyDescription2: Unlike Thai, Burmese, or Chinese, the Mon language is a non-tonal language; meaning it does not use changes in the pitch of the voice to distinguish the meaning of a word.
getStartView.historyDescription3: It‚Äôs thought to have evolved from an ancient Austroasiatic proto-language spoken across much of mainland Southeast Asia thousands of years ago.
getStartView.scriptItem1: The Mon script is classified abugida, wherein each consonantal character inherently includes a vowel sound unless modified.
getStartView.scriptItem2: The writing direction is left to right, in horizontal rows.
getStartView.comparisonTitle: Comparison to Vietnamese, Khmer, Thai, and Burmese
getStartView.funFactItem1: Mon language, unlike Thai or Burmese, is a non-tonal language meaning changes in pitch (how high or low the voice is) do not change the meaning of a word.

keyboardGuide.title: How to use Virtual Keyboard:
keyboardGuide.sect1Description: Please follow through each indicator as shown on the image above (Diagram #1) step-by-step from 1 to 5.
keyboardGuide.sect1No1: Keyboard layout: Comprised of interactive key buttons; each has its own Mon alphabet value. User can type any key on the keyboard layout to see the output on the text box.
keyboardGuide.sect1No2: Shift buttons: Positioned on the opposite side of each other; each works the same. When user press the button, the keyboard layout will display the rest of interactive buttons that also contain their own Mon alphabet values.
keyboardGuide.sect1No3: Text box: Used to display the text from user typing on the keyboard.
keyboardGuide.sect1No4: Copy text button: User can tap this button to copy the whole text from text box.
keyboardGuide.sect1No5: Keyboard switch buttons: In case if user wants to type in other languages. We are supporting the other 3 including English, Thai, and Burmese.
keyboardGuide.sect2Title: How a Mon word is constructed?
keyboardGuide.sect2Description: The image as shown above (Diagram #2) explains the alphabetical structure of how a single word can be constructed.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer1No1: Consonant: the initial alphabet to type. Sometimes, a single consonant can be a completed word and pronounciation on its own.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer1No2: Compound Consonant: (optional) the 2nd alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a compound consonant, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer2No1: Vowel: (optional) the 3rd alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a vowel alphabet, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer2No2: Final Consonant: (optional) the 4th alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a final consonant, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect3Title: For example if we are to type a word
keyboardGuide.sect3Description: The image as shown above (Diagram #3) explains the construction of the word "·ÄÄ·Äº·Ä±·Ä¨·Äï·Ä∫" (adj. crips, n. roofing tile) by implementing the concept from Diagram #2.
keyboardGuide.sect4Title: Now do it yourselves, following these steps
keyboardGuide.sect4Description: See the image above (Diagram #4) and follow the steps below.
keyboardGuide.sect4No1: First, press on key "·ÄÄ" as the initial consonant.
keyboardGuide.sect4No2: Then, press on key "·Äº" to combine the compound consonant with the consonant.
keyboardGuide.sect4No3: Now, to add the vowel "·Ä±·Ä¨", press on key "·Ä±" first to make it shift to the start of the word.
keyboardGuide.sect4No4: So, we can press on key "·Ä¨" to complete the vowel orderly.
keyboardGuide.sect4No5: Next, press on key "·Äï" to add the final consonant to the word. However, this is not a complete final consonant; as of right now, it is seen as single consonant with its own pronounciation.
keyboardGuide.sect4No6: To finish this, press on key "·Ä∫" to mark the late final consonant as really final consonant. Thus, this word is completed.
